text: I was one of the original investors in Leo's in 1988 or 89 (I forget now). The food got to be the best when Dave and Sheila brought in Donna, who had cooked at a place in L.A. called "Citi" (sp?). Donna went onto Bite on Western Ave next door to Empty Bottle. I don't know where she might have gone to from there but I think she is still in Chicago.   I guess the building was worth more to sell than to operate a restaurant and it seems to be an extension of the sushi place next door (the former Bop Shop).

I miss the days of leo's before it was sold to the group that eventually ran it into the ground. It was never the same after they cleaned it up and brought in that lame ass wait staff. I still haven't found a substitute for Leo's weekday breakfast.  Sunrise isn't cutting it for me.
WTF? This neighborhood is dead without Leo's. What's here now, another sushi counter or stiletto boutique? Ugh.

Closed?  I'm shocked.  Their "sausage" patties were so greasy and spicy I almost coughed one up.  I expect the other patrons here are too young to have had real food yet.  Or they just need something to replace the alcohol in their pores.
I miss the Georgia Reuben. I have painful cravings for this delicious sandwich, that will never ever be satisfied again. *tear* Will you take down your goddamn awning already!

What happened, Leo's? You were one of the best eateries in the neighborhood and then you had that weird makeover that included matching tableclothes and the awful mural of Chicago airbrushed onto the walls inside. Then, in the blink of an eye this past fall/winter season, you were closed. All of your breakfast, lunch, and dinner gubbins hit the spot. Your spicy turkey patties were exceptionally delicious. I pine for you, Leo's Lunchroom. I hope you are sipping on a cool drink out of a colorful aluminum tumbler in Restaraunt Heaven.
I think that Leo's is shut down.  (Booo Hooo!!!)  They had great sandwiches and even better Chili.
Leo's closed August 2005.  I don't know if the reviews after this date were purely reflective, but let it go.  They closed.  For good.  RIP LEO.

I mean--it's not like you can really fuck up breakfast food, or sandwiches and shit like that, but this place is still pretty good. I just hope it doesn't become overrun by the assholes in this neighborhood.

Does it make me a cranky old hipster to complain about change? Because that's basically what I've got here. The old gritty Leo's was so lovely and cheap; there wasn't anything else like it in or around Wicker Park. Now that new ownership's come in, they've cleaned it up so that the SWP/yuppie types that live in the area now will come there. It's not terrible. But it's not my favorite thing to see either. Gentrification has brought some good things to chicago, but the stripping and replacement of culture has just got to go. Wicker Park is slowly losing interesting bits of character that made people want to move there in the first place. Now that Leo's is out of my luncheon rolodex...it's across the street to Smoke Daddy, or nowhere else.

Despite its history as a small, dingy place, Leo's has long been a favorite breakfast spot, particularly with outdoor seating. The grungy days of the guy with the big mustache taking orders with photos and odds and ends flaking off the walls may be over, but the food is still great. My longtime favorite is the sweet potato breakfast burritos.

The first time I was taken to Leo's lunchroom, I absolutely loved it.  The spinach salad was tasty and giant, and my friend's soup and sandwich were both simple and good.  The atmosphere is homey and funky and laid-back.  I like the wood-paneled walls   The staff are straightforward and down to earth.  This is a great casual place to relax at.
Leo's isn't spectacular, but they get the job done. It is certainly the kind of place where you can feel instantly comfortable and there's something to be said for that.

Considering the "old" Leo's Lunchbox was my favorite place to eat in Chicago, I was a bit reluctant to try the restaurant since it got a new owner sometime last year. After being unable to get into a number of other places late one Friday night I found myself sitting in the new Leo's dining room. Overall the place is a bit less grungy (one of it original attributes, in my opinion) and the staff is more serious, but the food is still creative, delicious, and ample-portioned. I would skip dessert, however. One of the few carrot cakes I have ever disliked. Instead, I would recommend going to the Alliance Bakery across the street.

Some of the best chili I've ever had in a restaurant!  Great sandwiches and awesome chili with friendly service in a comfortable, clean atmosphere.  This place would be at home in New Orleans (something that can't be said for alot of places in Chicago) and they wouldn't have to change a thing.  Chili comes in vegetarian and meaty versions.  Leo's doesn't skimp on the good meats and cheeses, either.
